FieldValue.Value: Best evidence statement (BESt). Initial screening and referral for comorbidities in pediatric obese patients.

Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center. Best evidence statement (BESt). Initial screening and referral for comorbidities in pediatric obese patients. Cincinnati (OH): Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center; 2010 Sep 1. 6 p. [8 references]
This is the current release of the guideline.

ICD9CM: General physical examination (89.7); Morbid obesity (278.01); Obesity, unspecified (278.00); Organic sleep apnea, unspecified (327.20); Polycystic ovaries (256.4); Unspecified sleep apnea (780.57)

MSH: Antipsychotic Agents ; Aspartate Aminotransferases ; Blood Glucose ; Blood Pressure Determination ; Body Mass Index ; Comorbidity ; gamma-Glutamyltransferase ; Hemoglobin A, Glycosylated ; Medical History Taking ; Obesity ; Obesity, Morbid ; Physical Examination ; Polycystic Ovary Syndrome ; Referral and Consultation ; Sleep Apnea Syndromes ; Thyrotropin

MTH: Antilipemic agent ; Aspartate Transaminase ; Blood Glucose ; Blood pressure determination ; Body mass index procedure ; Fasting blood glucose measurement ; Gamma-glutamyl transferase ; Glycosylated hemoglobin A ; Hemoglobin A1c measurement ; Insulin measurement ; Obesity ; physical examination ; Polycystic Ovary Syndrome ; serum gamma glutamyl transpeptidase (GGTP) measurement ; Sleep Apnea Syndromes ; Thyroid stimulating hormone measurement ; Thyrotropin
PDQ: obesity

SNOMEDCT_US: Anti-psychotic agent (10784006); Anti-psychotic agent (372482001); Antilipemic agent (373267003); Antilipemic agent (57952007); Aspartate aminotransferase (26091008); Blood pressure taking (46973005); Family history of diabetes mellitus type 2 (430679000); Fasting blood glucose measurement (271062006); Fasting lipid profile (252150008); gamma-Glutamyltransferase (60153001); Glycosylated hemoglobin A (33601001); Hemoglobin A1c measurement (43396009); Insulin measurement (16890009); Morbid obesity (238136002); Obesity (414915002); Obesity (414916001); Organic sleep apnea (442164004); Physical assessment (302199004); Physical assessment (5880005); Physical assessment (81375008); Plasma aspartate transaminase measurement (313852007); Polycystic ovaries (69878008); Sleep apnea (73430006); Thyroid stimulating hormone measurement (61167004); Thyrotrophin product (326013007); Thyrotrophin product (65428006)
Pediatric obesity (body mass index [BMI] ≥95th percentile)
Family Practice
Internal Medicine
Advanced Practice Nurses
Physician Assistants

To evaluate what initial screening tests and clinical findings provide appropriate information to make specialty referrals so that identified comorbid conditions are managed to achieve best medical and quality of life outcomes, in children age 3 to 19 years, with body mass index (BMI) ≥95th percentile
Pediatric patients ages 3 to 19 years with body mass index (BMI) ≥95th percentile

1. Fasting laboratory studies
    • Insulin
    • Fasting glucose
    • Hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c)
    • Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)
    • Aspartate transaminase (AST)
    • Alanine transaminase (ALT)
    • Gamma glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT)
    • Lipid panel
  2. History and physical examination
    • Family history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (primary relative)
    • Medications, including antipsychotics
    • Clinical findings indicative of polycystic ovary syndrome (POS)
    • Blood pressure
    • History of exercise intolerance
    • Body mass index (BMI)
    • History of sleep apnea
  3. Comorbidity referrals

• Risk factors for comorbidities related to obesity
  • Quality of life

Table of Evidence Levels

Quality Level Definition
1a† or 1b† Systematic review, meta-analysis, or meta-synthesis of multiple studies
2a or 2b Best study design for domain
3a or 3b Fair study design for domain
4a or 4b Weak study design for domain
5 Other: General review, expert opinion, case report, consensus report, or guideline

†a = good quality study; b = lesser quality study

Field.Name: Rating Scheme for the Strength of the Recommendations

FieldValue.Value:
Table of Recommendation Strength

Strength Definition
"Strongly recommended" There is consensus that benefits clearly outweigh risks and burdens (or vice-versa for negative recommendations).
"Recommended" There is consensus that benefits are closely balanced with risks and burdens.
No recommendation made There is a lack of consensus to direct development of a recommendation.
Dimensions: In determining the strength of a recommendation, the development group makes a considered judgment in a consensus process that incorporates critically appraised evidence, clinical experience, and other dimensions as listed below.
  1. Grade of the Body of Evidence
  2. Safety/Harm
  3. Health benefit to the patients (direct benefit)
  4. Burden to patient of adherence to recommendation (cost, hassle, discomfort, pain, motivation, ability to adhere, time)
  5. Cost-effectiveness to healthcare system (balance of cost/savings of resources, staff time, and supplies based on published studies or onsite analysis)
  6. Directness (the extent to which the body of evidence directly answers the clinical question [population/problem, intervention, comparison, outcome])
  7. Impact on morbidity/mortality or quality of life
A formal cost analysis was not performed and published cost analyses were not reviewed.
Peer Review

Field.Name: Description of Method of Guideline Validation

FieldValue.Value: Reviewed against quality criteria by two independent reviewers.

The strength of the recommendation (strongly recommended, recommended, and no recommendation) and quality of the evidence (1a-5b) are defined at the end of the "Major Recommendations" field.

  1. It is recommended that the following fasting laboratory studies be obtained at the initial visit:
    • Insulin
    • Fasting glucose (August et al., 2008 [5b]; Kavey et al., 2006 [5b]; Silverstein et al., 2005 [5b])
    • HbA1c – hemoglobin A1c (American Diabetes Association, 2010 [5b]; Silverstein et al., 2005 [5b])
    • TSH – thyroid-stimulating hormone
    • AST – aspartate transaminase (Barlow & Expert Committee, 2007 [5b])
    • ALT – alanine transaminase (August et al., 2008 [5b]; Barlow & Expert Committee, 2007 [5b])
    • GGT – gamma glutamyl transpeptidase
    • Lipid panel (August et al., 2008 [5b]; Barlow & Expert Committee, 2007 [5b]; Kavey et al., 2006 [5b])

    (Local Consensus [5b])

    Note: Published clinical practice guidelines recommend not performing routine screening for thyroid disease (Barlow & Expert Committee, 2007 [5b]). Local consensus to conduct routine thyroid-stimulating hormone screening is recommended to avoid additional subsequent phlebotomy and testing is based on demand from patients and families.

  1. It is recommended that during the office visit a history and physical examination for comorbidities include the following:
    • Family history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (primary relative) (Barlow & Expert Committee, 2007 [5b]; Kavey et al., 2006 [5b]; Silverstein et al., 2005 [5b])
    • Medications, including antipsychotics
    • Clinical findings indicative of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), defined as two or more of the following:
      • Irregular periods and at least 2 years post menarche
      • Excessive acne
      • Hirsutism
      • Evidence of insulin resistance (acanthosis and/or elevated insulin >20 mg/dL)

        (August et al., 2008 [5b]; Barlow & Expert Committee, 2007 [5b]; Local Consensus [5b])

    • Blood pressure (August et al., 2008 [5b]; Barlow & Expert Committee, 2007 [5b]; Kavey et al., 2006 [5b])
    • History of exercise intolerance (Barlow & Expert Committee, 2007 [5b]; Kavey et al., 2006 [5b])
    • Body mass index (BMI) (August et al., 2008 [5b]; Barlow & Expert Committee, 2007 [5b]; Kavey et al., 2006 [5b])
    • History of sleep apnea (August et al., 2008 [5b]; Barlow & Expert Committee, 2007 [5b])

    (Local Consensus [5b])

  1. It is recommended that appropriate comorbidity referrals be made based upon these screening tests and clinical findings (see algorithm in the original guideline document) (Barlow & Expert Committee, 2007 [5b]; Silverstein et al., 2005 [5b]; Local Consensus [5b]).

    Note: It is out of scope to deal with follow up screening for normal findings.

A clinical algorithm is provided in the original guideline document for the evaluation for initial screening and referral for comorbidities in pediatric obese patients

Field.Name: Type of Evidence Supporting the Recommendations

FieldValue.Value: The type of supporting evidence is identified and graded for each recommendation (see the "Major Recommendations" field).

Section.Name: Benefits/Harms of Implementing the Guideline Recommendations

FieldValue.Value: Screening for current medical conditions and risks factors for other conditions lead to earlier interventions. Aggressive management of relative risk factors has been shown to improve outcomes and optimal management can modify one's risks.

• When body mass index (BMI) is <85th percentile, body fat levels are likely to pose little risk. BMI of 85th to the 94th percentile indicates health risks that vary yet the likelihood increases depending on body composition, BMI trajectory, and family history. The likelihood of obesity-related health risks increases to very likely for children with a BMI above the 95th percentile influenced by family medical history, current lifestyle habits, BMI trajectory and cardiovascular risk factors.
  • Adherence to the recommendations poses minimal risks and burden for venipunctures and history and physical, with little potential for additional unnecessary treatment and referrals from false positives. There is a potential burden for both the patient and health system for false positives regarding echocardiograms.

This Best Evidence Statement addresses only key points of care for the target population; it is not intended to be a comprehensive practice guideline. These recommendations result from review of literature and practices current at the time of their formulation. This Best Evidence Statement does not preclude using care modalities proven efficacious in studies published subsequent to the current revision of this document. This document is not intended to impose standards of care preventing selective variances from the recommendations to meet the specific and unique requirements of individual patients. Adherence to this Statement is voluntary. The clinician in light of the individual circumstances presented by the patient must make the ultimate judgment regarding the priority of any specific procedure.
An implementation strategy was not provided.

This NGC summary is based on the original full-text guideline, which is subject to the following copyright restrictions:

Copies of this Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center (CCHMC) Best Evidence Statement (BESt) are available online and may be distributed by any organization for the global purpose of improving child health outcomes. Examples of approved uses of the BESt include the following:

  • Copies may be provided to anyone involved in the organization's process for developing and implementing evidence based care;
  • Hyperlinks to the CCHMC website may be placed on the organization's website;
  • The BESt may be adopted or adapted for use within the organization, provided that CCHMC receives appropriate attribution on all written or electronic documents; and
  • Copies may be provided to patients and the clinicians who manage their care.

Notification of CCHMC at EBDMInfo@cchmc.org for any BESt adopted, adapted, implemented or hyperlinked by the by the organization is appreciated.
